11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Stand Up for Yourself at Work","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If you're being disrespected, bullied, or mistreated at work, it's important to stand up for yourself. This can be pretty uncomfortable, though, especially if being assertive doesn't come naturally to you. We totally understand! To help you out, we've compiled a list of ways to handle a variety of workplace scenarios. Don't be afraid to speak up for yourself on the job—you absolutely deserve respect and fair treatment. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Stay calm no matter what.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stay-calm-no-matter-what.\">Stay calm no matter what.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Reacting in anger may come off as aggressive rather than assertive. We know it's not always easy to keep your cool in a tough situation, but do your best. Pause, take a few deep breaths, and give yourself a moment to think before saying anything. If you clap back in the heat of the moment, you may end up looking like the perpetrator rather than the victim.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you need to, walk away for a few minutes to collect yourself. Once you're calmer, go back and address the situation in a civil, professional way.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you're feeling upset about something, ask yourself, \"How important is this right now? Is it going to be important a week from now?\" That can help you get perspective on the issue.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>A calm, assertive response is a good thing! It’s a healthy way to let others know what you need and how you feel.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Disagree with colleagues respectfully.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Disagree-with-colleagues-respectfully.\">Disagree with colleagues respectfully.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Speak up without tearing the other person down. If you disagree with a colleague’s opinion or solution to a problem, there's nothing wrong with speaking up about it. Try to avoid pitting your idea against theirs, though, which can seem aggressive. Instead, acknowledge the value of the other person’s idea before introducing your own.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-2.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, \"Kathy’s proposal is solid and going that route could definitely benefit the company. I have another idea that may help us reach our quarterly goal even faster, though. What does everyone think about...\"</li> \n    <li>If you don't like the way your manager assigns shifts, politely offer an alternate solution. For example, “Mr. Sellers, I really appreciate that you want our shift assignments to be fair. Your recent changes got me thinking and I'd love to get your perspective on this alternative...”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Address problems quickly.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Address-problems-quickly.\">Address problems quickly.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>A firm verbal response is the most effective approach. If a coworker says or does something inappropriate, don’t go back to your desk and stew all day. Call out their bad behavior right away to nip it in the bud. Remember to stay calm, but use firm, direct language to tell them the behavior is unacceptable and needs to stop immediately.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-3.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if someone calls you “Honey” in a meeting, immediately respond with, “I don’t like being called that. Please use my name to address me.”</li> \n    <li>If a coworker tries to take credit for your work in a project meeting, let them finish speaking. Then, politely note your own contributions. For example, “Bill did a great job organizing the reports. With his help, I was able to analyze and file them a lot faster than usual.”</li> \n    <li>If you don’t speak up quickly, your coworker (and anyone else who witnessed the act) will think it’s fine to treat you that way.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Talk to the person in private.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Talk-to-the-person-in-private.\">Talk to the person in private.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>They may not react well if you call them out in public. Aside from that, sometimes a public confrontation just doesn't feel quite right for that particular situation. For example, if a coworker talks over you in a meeting and they've never done that before, give them the benefit of the doubt! Wait until the meeting is over and talk to them about it privately.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-4.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might say take them aside later and say, \"I realize you probably didn't mean to do this, but when you interrupted me at the meeting earlier, I felt belittled and a bit embarrassed. Can you be more careful about that in the future?\"</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Use questions instead of accusations.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Use-questions-instead-of-accusations.\">Use questions instead of accusations.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Questions feel less confrontational. If you need to have a tough conversation with a colleague, try to avoid opening with aggressive statements like “I don’t like the way you’re doing this” or “I think your approach is wrong.” The person will immediately feel judged and probably get defensive. You can still be assertive and speak your mind with questions.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup> For example:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-5.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>\"Can you help me understand why Derrick got most of my assignments this week? Are you unhappy with the quality of my work?\"</li> \n    <li>\"I'm not sure I understand why you CC'd the sales team on that email. I thought we were talking privately. Can you tell me why you did that?\"</li> \n    <li>\"Would you mind explaining the new schedule? I know you must have a good reason for making changes, but our lunch breaks are 15 minutes shorter now.\"</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Unite with coworkers against a bully.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Unite-with-coworkers-against-a-bully.\">Unite with coworkers against a bully.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Bullies tend to assume their victims will stay quiet out of shame. If you’re being bullied by a coworker, don’t suffer in silence. Reach out to other coworkers who you trust and ask them if they've had any issues with the bully in the past. Bullying behavior is usually a pattern, so other people will probably come forward. Band together, discuss the situation, and support each other.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-6.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Come up with a game plan together. Your boss is more likely to take your complaint seriously if other employees back you up.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Look at the situation objectively.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Look-at-the-situation-objectively.\">Look at the situation objectively.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Some issues require a stronger response than others. If you’re being bullied, treated unfairly, or harassed at work, you absolutely need to stand up for yourself. Responding in the heat of the moment is never wise, though, so take a moment to step back and look at the situation before you escalate things.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> Unacceptable behaviors include:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-7.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Coworkers gossiping about you or purposely excluding you</li> \n    <li>Verbal abuse, yelling, or using profanity</li> \n    <li>Purposely unclear tasks and unreasonable workloads</li> \n    <li>Employees taking credit for your work</li> \n    <li>Offensive jokes, nicknames, or comments</li> \n    <li>Constant criticism, discrimination, or undeserved punishment</li> \n    <li>Blocking opportunities for training or advancement<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Collect evidence for a formal complaint.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Collect-evidence-for-a-formal-complaint.\">Collect evidence for a formal complaint.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You'll need some proof if you plan to make a formal complaint. Try keeping a daily journal to jot down incidents as they occur. Include the date, time, and as much detail about the event as possible (including names of any witnesses). Save any memos, emails, and other written communication, too.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-8.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Bring issues to your supervisor first.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Bring-issues-to-your-supervisor-first.\">Bring issues to your supervisor first.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>This is the most professional way to handle a problem. If you need to take action or make a formal complaint about someone, go to your immediate supervisor first (assuming this person isn’t the perpetrator). If you escalate an issue over your boss's head, they'll be blind sighted when the formal investigation starts (which doesn’t reflect well on you).<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-9.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might say, \"Rebecca, do you have a few minutes to speak to me privately in your office? I would love to get your perspective on some things I’ve been dealing with lately.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Go to HR if nothing improves.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Go-to-HR-if-nothing-improves.\">Go to HR if nothing improves.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Do what you need to do to stand up for your rights at work. If your boss downplays or ignores your complaints, feel free to escalate the issue to the next level of management or go straight to HR. Be sure to bring all of your evidence to back up your claims.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stand Up for Yourself at Work Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-10.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you feel like you need to speak up because you're overwhelmed or you're facing an unreasonable deadline, schedule a conversation with your boss where you make sure you're aligned on your responsibilities, goals, and expectations.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://hbr.org/2014/10/how-to-deal-with-a-mean-colleague\">https://hbr.org/2014/10/how-to-deal-with-a-mean-colleague</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://hbr.org/2015/06/how-to-speak-up-about-ethical-issues-at-work\">https://hbr.org/2015/06/how-to-speak-up-about-ethical-issues-at-work</a></span> </li> \n   <li noopener\" class=\"external free\" <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://hbr.org/2014/10/how-to-deal-with-a-mean-colleague\">https://hbr.org/2014/10/how-to-deal-with-a-mean-colleague</a></span> </li> \n   <li noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html\">https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html\">https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li \n   <li id=\"_note-15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-15\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html\">https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/psychosocial/bullying.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161315_b01]. 27 March 2020.</span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 11 Aug 2021 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"dab755145a0cc351130b4ef3200027e0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn6@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-24-720_280d986af2a1f33a.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":77760,"destBytes":38872,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn6@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-24-720_280d986af2a1f33a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-2.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn29@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-30-876_cfd9d65bf023a3ec.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-3.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn45@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-536_71d2d1b7c2ca31a2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-4.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn78@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-328_a30fa58a051b57f9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-5.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn33@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-29-444_879dfa432c1fbfeb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-6.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn89@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-29-556_07a71f439655125e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-7.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn13@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-41-079_e286eb7351874bce.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-8.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn89@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-30-129_672dcfc5749e858e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-9.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn29@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-30-599_b2fbd53605622141.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-10.jpg/aid12660650-v4-728px-Stand-Up-for-Yourself-at-Work-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn14@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-32-356_e40f7edd366d3279.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590247},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Paint an Ombre Canvas","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If DIY wall art seems intimidating, try out an ombre canvas painting instead! This project is quick and easy, and lets you tap into your creative side without too much pressure. Prepare your space and supplies, then apply paint to your canvas in even, straight strokes that gradually grows lighter or darker. You can either blend while you paint or afterward with a wet brush. Let your paint dry and then add some spray varnish to seal your masterpiece! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Gathering Supplies\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Gathering-Supplies\">Gathering Supplies</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Lay down a drop cloth or piece of cardboard to keep the area clean. This project can easily get messy, so make sure to protect the area around you. You can use a sheet of plastic, a canvas drop cloth, a piece of cardboard, or even an old sheet to catch any spills.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Some good areas to paint include outdoors, on cement or blacktop, or on a flat surface indoors, such as a table or hardwood floor.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Choose a canvas size and some flat paint brushes. For your base, choose a stretched canvas in whatever size you would like. To achieve the smooth, blended look of an ombre painting, you'll also need some flat, wide-bristle brushes. Though you can adjust your brush sizes based on the size of your canvas, or brushes often work well with most sizes.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you could start by experimenting on small canvases, which include or .</li> \n    <li>Medium-sized canvases are perfect for hanging and displaying. They can range from to .</li> \n    <li>Large canvases make for eye-catching statement pieces. They often range in size from to .</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Squeeze out a large amount of each acrylic paint color onto your palette. Make sure to use acrylic paint that you can paint with straight out of the tube. Once you've chosen the 2 paint colors you'll be using, pour them next to each other onto your palette. Leave some space for mixing the 2 colors together. Adjust the amounts of paint depending on the size of canvas you'll be using.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you're painting an canvas, you'll likely need to squeeze out a circle of each paint color on your palette.</li> \n    <li>For a simple, authentic ombre effect, only use 2 colors. Adding in extra colors makes the mixing complicated, and the result won't have a true ombre effect.</li> \n    <li>You can use a cheap plastic palette, paper plate, square of glass, or ceramic plate for a palette. Keep in mind that a disposable palette can make the clean-up process a lot easier!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix a few drops of retarder into the paint to slow the drying process. A retarder is an agent that you can add to the paint to slow its drying time and make it easier to blend.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> Acrylic paint dries very quickly, so a retarder can take some of the pressure off while you figure out the ombre process. Once your paint is on your palette, use clean brushes or popsicle sticks to mix in a few drops of retarder with each different paint color.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find retarder at art supply stores or online.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Applying Paint\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Applying-Paint\">Applying Paint</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Apply paint to the canvas in even, straight strokes. Flip the canvas on its side, landscape style, and paint in vertical strokes from one side to other. This technique will help keep your strokes regular and even, all going the same direction. Your finished piece will look much smoother and blend out more easily if your brushstrokes match.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want a wrap-around effect, make sure to paint all the way to the edges and over the sides as well.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Keep the paint thick and wet so it doesn't dry out before you can blend. Always load up your brush with plenty of paint before applying it to the canvas. This will give you enough paint on the canvas to blend together, and it will also slow down the drying process.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The retarder will also help slow down the drying process and make the paint more blending. Keeping the paint thick will add to this effect, giving you lots of time to perfect your ombre effect!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Start with white paint and mix in more color if you want a light gradient. Load your brush with white paint and use it to cover the bottom of the canvas. On your palette, dip your brush into the colored paint and mix it into the white paint. Apply this light shade as the next horizontal stripe to the canvas.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep repeating this step and incorporating more color into the paint until you reach the bottom of the canvas. Use pure color for the last stripe</li> \n    <li>You could pick a color combination like cerulean blue and titanium white for an ocean or sky effect. You could also try a bright, lively combination of fuschia and white.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Start with a lighter color and add black paint for a dark gradient. It's easier to transition a paint color from light to dark than it is to lighten a dark paint color. Apply of your pure light color to the end of the canvas. In your palette, mix some black into the paint color until you have a slightly darker shade of the same color. Add another stripe directly beside the first, then repeat this process until you fill up the canvas.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Paint the darkest shade or pure black at the end of the canvas to complete the gradient.</li> \n    <li>You could use a blue-to-black gradient for a moody night-sky effect.</li> \n    <li>You could also opt for a white-to-black color scheme for a neutral, minimalist piece.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pick 2 colors to transition from one color to another. Start with a stripe of the lightest color, then add in a bit of the darker color stripe by stripe. Continue darkening the paint stripes until you reach the last stripe, which should be a pure of stripe of the darker color.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you could create an ombre effect from pink to blue or from yellow to forest green.</li> \n    <li>Practice blending the two paints before you begin your project. For example, red and green can create a muddy brown color, which may not be the look you're going for.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Creating an Ombre Effect\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-an-Ombre-Effect\">Creating an Ombre Effect</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Work the stripes into each other as you paint for a smooth effect. If you want an ultra-smooth gradient, create the ombre effect as you paint. When you add a new stripe, drag your brush back and forth between the new stripe and the previous stripe until they blend together. This will create a seamless transition between each shade.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Add a bit of water to your brush for blending if the paint starts to dry out. If you paint your stripes quickly or add retarder, you can wait until you've filled up the canvas to blend. Dip the brush in water before running it over the stripes of paint. Brush up and down in the same direction as your painted brush strokes, blending each stripe into the next.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be careful not to add too much water, since it alters the opacity of the paint.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Leave the stripes unblended for a blocky, modern piece of wall art. If you like the look of each defined stripe, you can skip the blending step. For a more abstract-art effect, drag the brush down the canvas until the brush naturally runs out of paint and creates rough edge.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Let the paint dry overnight. Depending on how thick your paint is, your painting may feel dry to the touch within 20-30 minutes. However, there may still be moisture trapped beneath the outer dried layer, which will need more time to dry. Let the painting sit overnight to dry more fully.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Add 2-3 coats of varnish spray to give the paint a quick, polished finish. Once your paint is dry, spray on 2 or 3 coats of varnish finishing spray. Let the varnish coat dry overnight before hanging or displaying your new piece artwork.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Paint an Ombre Canvas Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find varnish spray at craft or art supply stores.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>A stretched canvas</li> \n  <li>Acrylic paint</li> \n  <li>Wide bristle paint brush</li> \n  <li>Jar of water</li> \n  <li>Paint palette or a paper plate</li> \n  <li>Drop cloth or piece of cardboard</li> \n  <li>Varnish spray</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.cityline.tv/2016/03/21/diy-ombre-canvas-wall-art/\">http://www.cityline.tv/2016/03/21/diy-ombre-canvas-wall-art/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.artinstructionblog.com/acrylic-painting-tip-how-long-do-acrylic-paints-take-to-dry\">http://www.artinstructionblog.com/acrylic-painting-tip-how-long-do-acrylic-paints-take-to-dry</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 07 Aug 2021 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"bec65891a76bd2ad0024729d813f3e28","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-10-833_3f2713476e6980c0.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":45922,"destBytes":21262,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-10-833_3f2713476e6980c0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn9@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-30-768_b57ac7813a295a9a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn58@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-624_be68abb4c5d2b276.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn14@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-31-164_40cab552cd1042d2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn22@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-30-725_f0cf177ecf5b78c3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn1@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-40-113_d7d521090cda76de.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn21@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-29-994_6d6cb3a100ec6755.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid9613663-v4-728px-Paint-an-Ombre-Canvas-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn94@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-31-951_c5e27d9334a558bc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590217},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Help an Angry Toddler","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Whoever called it the “terrible twos” may have been onto something! With their wide range of emotions, increased mobility, and seemingly endless energy, toddlers bring a whole new set of challenges to parenting. If you’re wondering how you can help settle an angry toddler, have no fear. There really are a few tricks that work. To help you out, we’ve put together a list of tips and strategies you can use to calm your little one down when they get upset. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Give them a mindfulness jar if they’re overwhelmed.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Give-them-a-mindfulness-jar-if-they’re-overwhelmed.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Give-them-a-mindfulness-jar-if-they.E2.80.99re-overwhelmed.\">Give them a mindfulness jar if they’re overwhelmed.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>They’re easy to make and super effective. A mindfulness jar a visual sensory tool that can distract and help a child relax when they get worked up. To make one, fill a clear plastic bottle about ¾ of the way full with hot water, add of clear gel glue and some glitter, then seal the cap and shake it up well. Whenever your toddler is throwing an angry fit, give them the mindfulness jar and see if that helps settle them.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can add a few drops of superglue to the lid when you close it so it stays sealed shut.</li> \n    <li>Go crazy with different kinds of glitter! Give your little one a ton of colors to look at floating around inside.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Put on some music if your toddler is crying.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Put-on-some-music-if-your-toddler-is-crying.\">Put on some music if your toddler is crying.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It can actually calm their nervous system. Play some music for your kiddo if they’re really upset and crying and it could turn their mood around. It may get them up and dancing along, but the music can also decrease their heart and respiratory rate, which can naturally calm them down.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You don’t have to stick to nursery rhymes, either! Some uptempo pop music can work just as well or even better than a lullaby. Try out some different music and see what your toddler likes.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Ask them to talk instead of whining or yelling.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ask-them-to-talk-instead-of-whining-or-yelling.\">Ask them to talk instead of whining or yelling.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Encourage them to use their words and talk about their feelings. Toddlers can easily get themselves worked up, so try catching them before it happens. When your little one starts to shout or whine when they’re telling you something that’s upsetting them or talking about something that they want, calmly correct them and ask them to use their words and speak clearly. It can help them focus on what they’re saying, which may help avoid a meltdown.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It can be frustrating to be misunderstood! If a toddler is having trouble communicating, having them slow down and focus on speaking clearly can help.</li> \n    <li>Try, “Sweetheart, I can’t understand you when you whine. Use your words and tell me about it, okay?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Listen and respond to your toddler when they talk to you.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Listen-and-respond-to-your-toddler-when-they-talk-to-you.\">Listen and respond to your toddler when they talk to you.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Get on their level and show them that you understand. Allow them to take their time and put their feelings into words. Really listen to what they’re saying and respond kindly so they know that you understand them. It can make a world of a difference to a toddler if they feel like they’re understood. Try offering up a few words of encouragement and comfort to make them feel better if they’re upset about what they’re telling you as well.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It may also help to literally get on their level. Lower down so you’re at their eye-level and you don’t seem like such a towering figure.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Try saying things like, “That must have made you upset” and “Did it hurt your feelings?” or “That must be frustrating, huh sweetie?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Give them a healthy way to let off some steam.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Give-them-a-healthy-way-to-let-off-some-steam.\">Give them a healthy way to let off some steam.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>They can run around or draw a picture to release their anger. This might not be news to you, but toddlers have a ton of energy! Sometimes it’s best to not fight it and instead redirect it somewhere else.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> Tell your toddler to run to the fence and back, do some jumping jacks (if they’re able to do them), or just have them jump up and down. You could also ask them to draw you a picture of something so they’ll focus their energy on that.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There are all sorts of ways you can get your kiddo to focus their energy on something else. Get creative! Have them dig a hole in the yard, play tug of war with them, or wrestle with them.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Stick to positive reinforcement.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stick-to-positive-reinforcement.\">Stick to positive reinforcement.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Threats and punishments won’t work on a toddler. Avoid giving a toddler ultimatums. It can easily backfire on you. Instead, focus on promoting the behavior you want from them by positively reinforcing the idea.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> They’re much more likely to respond to you that way.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, try, “I understand, sweetie, but if you want to watch the movie then we need to finish lunch first. If not, it’s no big deal, we can always try again later.” Instead of something like, “You need to eat your lunch or else!”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Set up a special play area for them.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Set-up-a-special-play-area-for-them.\">Set up a special play area for them.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Give them a separate area to play and explore. A toddler may not understand or get angry when there are things in your home that they can’t touch or play with. Try setting up a playpen that has a bunch of toys and activities that they can play with as much as they want. That way, they can let out some energy and they won’t get upset when there’s something they can’t do.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you don’t want your toddler to pull books off of your shelf, try setting up some of their picture books in a play area so they can take them out, play with them, or flip through them as much as they want.</li> \n    <li>Another advantage of a playpen is you have somewhere to put your toddler where you know they’re safe and can’t get into anything dangerous.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Find what triggers your toddler’s tantrums.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Find-what-triggers-your-toddler’s-tantrums.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Find-what-triggers-your-toddler.E2.80.99s-tantrums.\">Find what triggers your toddler’s tantrums.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>If you can identify the problem, you can avoid future meltdowns. Pay attention to what seems to be upsetting your little one. If they’re avoidable or if you can make adjustments that will help keep them from getting upset, give it a shot! You might be able to save yourself a lot of potential headaches.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if your toddler prefers to use a certain sippy cup and gets upset when you try to give them a different one, try to make sure the one they like is available when you need it.</li> \n    <li>Of course, some things that upset a toddler may be unavoidable, such as getting dressed or having to bathe when they don’t want to. But there may be other things you can avoid to help keep them from getting angry.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Talk about house rules often with your toddler.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Talk-about-house-rules-often-with-your-toddler.\">Talk about house rules often with your toddler.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Phrase them as positives so they’re more likely to follow them. Don’t wait until your little one breaks a rule to tell them about them. Instead, calmly bring up and talk about different rules regularly so they get the message loud and clear (it can take toddlers a little while). Talk about what’s okay and what’s not okay using fun and friendly terms so they don’t harsh or scary.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, you can call time-out a “time-in” or say, “Quiet feet!” instead of, “No running!”</li> \n    <li>While you’re walking around your home with your toddler, you can say things like, “And those are shoes, see? And we don’t take shoes and move them, right? We leave them right where they are.”</li> \n    <li>Use positive language and an uplifting tone to say things like, “And look! There’s a kitty cat! Remember, we don’t pull on a cat’s tail right? Because that can hurt the cat.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Use time-outs for whenever they break the rules.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Use-time-outs-for-whenever-they-break-the-rules.\">Use time-outs for whenever they break the rules.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It’s a simple way to help them settle down. Whenever your toddler is breaking rules, getting upset, or throwing a full-on tantrum, words may not be enough to calm them down. When that happens, remove them from the situation and have them sit somewhere quietly for a couple of minutes. Once they relax and stop throwing a fit, you can let them out and talk to them about it.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For 2-year-olds, stick to around 2 minutes for a time-out. A good rule of thumb is 1 minute for each year of age.</li> \n    <li>If your toddler leaves the time-out area, gently put them back into it and restart the time-out clock. If they throw a major tantrum, just ignore it unless there’s actually a possibility that they could hurt themselves.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Praise your kiddo when they behave appropriately.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Praise-your-kiddo-when-they-behave-appropriately.\">Praise your kiddo when they behave appropriately.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It can help reinforce it. It’s actually almost more important that you give your child credit and praise whenever they do something right so they’re more motivated to keep doing the right thing. Don’t hold back! Tell them how great they are and what a good job they did. Get really animated and make a big deal about it. It’ll make them smile and they’ll love getting all the extra attention.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your toddler picks up their shoes and socks, tell them, “Wow! Look at you! What a great job! So helpful, thank you!”</li> \n    <li>If they share a toy with a sibling or another toddler, heap the praise on them by saying, “Very nice! That’s so sweet of you to share. Great job!”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Teach your toddler to say “no” instead of fighting.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Teach-your-toddler-to-say-“no”-instead-of-fighting.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Teach-your-toddler-to-say-.E2.80.9Cno.E2.80.9D-instead-of-fighting.\">Teach your toddler to say “no” instead of fighting.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Help them find a better way to stand up for themselves. When a toddler gets upset with other children, they may resort to getting physical or shouting at them. Tell your little one that they can calmly tell other kids, “No” with a firm tone of voice. They can also turn away or leave the situation if it’s making them upset. It’ll help them learn to establish healthy boundaries from a young age and avoid resorting to violence when they’re angry.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try saying, “So if the other kids want to take your toy, just say ‘No, thank you. I’m playing with it right now.’”</li> \n    <li>You can also gently remind them of rules by saying, “Remember, we don’t hit other people. We are nice to them. If we don’t like what they’re doing, we say, ‘No, thank you.’”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: Make sure your toddler gets enough sleep.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Make-sure-your-toddler-gets-enough-sleep.\">Make sure your toddler gets enough sleep.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It can make a huge difference. It may seem simple or like a no-brainer, but toddlers are much more likely to lose their temper if they’re tired. Put them down to bed around the same time each night and make sure they get a nap if they need one. It could save you (and your little one) a whole lot of frustration.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Kids between the ages of 1 and 2 need around 11-14 hours of sleep each day, including at least 1 nap.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15\" title=\"Edit section: Control your own temper.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Control-your-own-temper.\">Control your own temper.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Set a good example for your little one. It’s completely normal and natural to get frustrated, but it’s important that your toddler sees you handle your frustrations in a calm and mature way. If you get upset or angry at your toddler or anyone else, express it using quiet, peaceful words. Don’t shout, stomp around, or storm off or your toddler just may mimic you!<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Help-an-Angry-Toddler#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Help an Angry Toddler Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid12685726-v4-728px-Help-an-Angry-Toddler-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>That goes for everyday activities, too. If someone cuts you off in traffic, for example, don’t shout at them or curse them out. Your little one is always watching how you handle things and learning from you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Sometimes just removing your toddler from the situation is enough to get them to settle down. If they’re really upset about something, try picking them up, carrying them away, and calmly talking to them about it.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Help-an-Angry-Toddler&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap
