</div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 06 Aug 2021 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"c1283508e8f0342e06a78e95e0f41842","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn47@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-24-599_f1ab03567eecb181.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":49502,"destBytes":24412,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn47@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-24-599_f1ab03567eecb181.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn36@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-29-537_ead1cc4fbf69e76f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn54@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-609_faf91f8a6f3c3462.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn57@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-28-947_7e25756c2c67ebad.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-32-176_f36c1ce8f42f3614.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn33@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-30-233_5e5af4973ee0b619.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn28@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-29-527_326020ca8b398db6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-31-058_9f87886fcba3cb68.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn78@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-31-089_f1711b5011974a91.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn65@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-30-409_bcf50c08a8d07f95.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid96555-v4-728px-Treat-a-Fire-Ant-Sting-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn66@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-047_5e81c74b5e0ed35c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590248},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If there’s a special guy in your life, chances are he’s on your mind 24/7. So it’s perfectly natural for you to wonder whether or not he’s thinking of you. Fortunately, you don’t have to guess! There are actually plenty of ways you can figure out if a guy is thinking about you. To help you out, we’ve put together a list of signs and clues you can look for to tell you if he’s got you on his mind. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: He texts you good morning and good night.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-texts-you-good-morning-and-good-night.\">He texts you good morning and good night.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You’re on his mind day and night. If a guy sends you a good morning text, then you were one of the first things he thought about that day (he maybe even dreamt about you). A good night text is a clear message that you were on his mind as he was winding down his day and getting ready to go to sleep. Both messages are huge signs that the guy can’t stop thinking about you.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It could be something simple like, “Good morning!” or something a little more flirty like, “Hey beautiful. Good morning.”</li> \n    <li>Even if you haven’t talked much during the day, if a guy texts you, “Hey, hope you had a great day. Talk to you tomorrow,” it means he just couldn’t rest until he talked to you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: He sends you random messages all day long.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-sends-you-random-messages-all-day-long.\">He sends you random messages all day long.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It could be a sign that he can’t get you out of his head. While a message here and there may seem insignificant, it actually means that you were on his mind and he just had to reach out to you. It could be a meme, a short message, or even a link to an article or video, the point is that he wants you to know he was thinking about you.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-2.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If he sends you a meme that is specific to your sense of humor, it means he saw it and immediately thought of you.</li> \n    <li>If he sends you a link to an article, it’s likely that he read it and wanted to share it with you. That’s a pretty clear signal that he’s thinking of you!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: He asks you lots of questions.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-asks-you-lots-of-questions.\">He asks you lots of questions.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>It means he wants to get to know more about you. If he wants to know more about you, it’s likely that he’s been thinking about you.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> He may also ask you questions or get your opinion about something to see what you think, which is another major clue that you’re often on his mind.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-3.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If he says, “I was wondering what you like to do for fun. Do you have any hobbies?” then he was thinking of you and wanted to ask.</li> \n    <li>It can be something small, too. If he says, “I love Buffalo wings with blue cheese, and I was wondering if you think they go together, too?” it means he was thinking about you and wanted to know your opinion!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: He double-texts you.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-double-texts-you.\">He double-texts you.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>If he’s got you on his mind, he won’t care how it looks. Double-texting, a.k.a. sending multiple texts in a row, is usually a no-no that can make you come off as too strong. But if a guy can’t stop thinking about you, chances are he won’t be self-conscious about messaging you back-to-back.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-4.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re into him, don’t leave him hanging! Message him back so he doesn’t feel like he’s putting himself out there for nothing.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: He likes and comments on your social media posts.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-likes-and-comments-on-your-social-media-posts.\">He likes and comments on your social media posts.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He wants you to know he's checking you out. If he likes a post or a picture you posted, then he’s obviously thinking of you because he saw your post. If he takes it a step further and comments on it, he may be trying to initiate a conversation or just send a clear signal that it left an impression on him.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-5.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if he comments something like “Love this” or if he leaves a bunch of flame or heart emojis, then he definitely likes what he sees.</li> \n    <li>If he likes or responds to an older post or picture, then he may have been thinking of you so much that he searched through your profile and couldn’t help but react.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: He messages you when he’s with his friends.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"He-messages-you-when-he’s-with-his-friends.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-messages-you-when-he.E2.80.99s-with-his-friends.\">He messages you when he’s with his friends.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He could easily just hang out with them instead. If you get a message from a guy while he’s with his buddies, that’s a big deal! It means that even while he’s spending time with his friends, you’re on his mind.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-6.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If he says, “Hey what are you up to?” and you know he’s with his friends, try teasing him a bit with, “Not much, aren’t you supposed to be with your friends?” He might respond with something like, “Yeah, but I’d rather be with you.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: He talks about how something reminded him of you.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-talks-about-how-something-reminded-him-of-you.\">He talks about how something reminded him of you.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He can’t help but think of you. If he messages you to say that he heard a song, saw a video, read an article, or was doing something that made him think of you, it’s not an accident. It means he’s been thinking of you and he had to tell you about it.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-7.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if he says, “I was watching a movie the other day and it reminded me of the time we went to the theaters and I spilled my drink all over the seat!” it means you were on his mind even when he was doing something else.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: He remembers everything you tell him.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-remembers-everything-you-tell-him.\">He remembers everything you tell him.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He listens and cares about you.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup> It’s easy enough for your friends to remember your birthday or what your favorite sports team is. But if a guy knows exactly how you like your eggs cooked or what books you like to read, it means he’s trying hard to know as much about you as possible, and you’re on his mind a lot. He also probably really likes you.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-8.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For instance, if you get a message from a guy wishing you good luck on a test that you briefly mentioned to him before, it means he’s thinking of you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: He surprises you with things you like.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-surprises-you-with-things-you-like.\">He surprises you with things you like.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He’s paying attention to you and your interests. If you get a gift from a guy that seems tailored to your interests, then he obviously thought of you whenever he saw it. He just had to get it and give it to you!<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-9.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you told a guy that your favorite TV show is <i>Dr. Who</i>, and he gets you a stuffed TARDIS as a gift, then he’s obviously paying attention to you and thinking about you!</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: He tells you he misses you.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-tells-you-he-misses-you.\">He tells you he misses you.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He really likes you and can’t stop thinking about you. Think about it: it’s a big deal to just come out and tell someone you miss them. If a guy says it to you, he likely means it. He’s probably had you on his mind all day long and he just had to tell you about it.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-10.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If he says, “Hey, I miss you. How’s your day going?” or “I miss your face,” he’s definitely been thinking of you.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: He talks about future plans with you.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"He-talks-about-future-plans-with-you.\">He talks about future plans with you.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>He may be thinking about you in the long term. If he talks about a new movie coming out that he wants to go see and he asks you if you’d be interested in going, it means he thinks of you as being present in his life in the future. If he has upcoming plans like a wedding or an office party, and he mentions that he’d like you to go with him, then it means that whenever he thinks about a date, he thinks of you!<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Know if a Guy Is Thinking About You Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-11.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It may seem simple or like it’s not a big deal, but he’s talking about doing things with you weeks, months, or even years down the line, then you’re definitely on his mind.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you’re close to his friends, you could try asking one of them if he talks about you for a sign that you’re on his mind.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"0ff50e50ac99c8e5a44a959daa866778","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn52@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-24-580_f4943994f49b3ef3.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":86239,"destBytes":47740,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn52@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-24-580_f4943994f49b3ef3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-2.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn13@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-30-119_4d6ed7aa7733ef57.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-3.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn37@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-30-199_e339b32cb28b9fa7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-4.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn10@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-29-227_3f8b620d22188fc8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-5.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn93@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-30-327_27e04e7a3e8ec200.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-6.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn32@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-29-539_debdd39a9afacec4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-7.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn94@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-40-583_e7a3d552b1152c94.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-8.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn27@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-29-101_71c2c7564cf81041.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-9.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn86@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-30-046_4f1cc43650aafb30.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-10.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn90@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-31-471_2cfb5db3ce4ec8c4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-11.jpg/aid12684250-v4-728px-Know-if-a-Guy-Is-Thinking-About-You-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn6@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-30-777_f0a84d2775ab4df2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590217},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Learn to Swim As an Adult","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Swimming is a great way to stay fit and have fun in the water, and it can be learned at any age. Whether you’ve never set foot in a pool before or just need a refresher, you can become a competent swimmer with a little effort and a positive attitude. Gradually get used to moving and breathing in the water, learn some basic strokes, and consider taking adult swim lessons to perfect your technique.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Comfortable in the Water\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Comfortable-in-the-Water\">Getting Comfortable in the Water</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Spend some time in the shallow end of the pool. If you don’t have much experience in the water, it can be helpful to get comfortable just being in the pool before you tackle swimming. Spend some time moving around in water that is shallow enough that you can stand on the bottom of the pool with your head still above the water.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Buy ear plugs and goggles to make swimming more comfortable. Having water in your eyes and ears isn’t necessarily a bad thing, but it can feel strange and distracting when you first begin swimming. Chlorine can also irritate your eyes and ears over time, so it’s a good idea to be prepared with goggles and ear plugs.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try goggles on before buying them, and make sure they fit tightly without causing uncomfortable pressure on the bridge of your nose.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Practice holding your breath with your face underwater. Putting your face in the water can be a little intimidating at first, but after a few times it will feel natural. Stand with your body as far into the water as you’re comfortable with, then hold your breath and dip your face into the water.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-3.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once that feels comfortable, you can try submerging your whole body in the shallow end while holding your breath.</li> \n    <li>If you’re worried about water entering your nose, you can pinch your nostrils shut with your fingers.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Don't blow out the air in your lungs while you're under the water—that will make you less buoyant.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Have a friend pull you through the water while you float on your back. Once you’re in the water, lean back and spread your arms and legs out. Have someone take one of your hands and pull you slowly through the water. This is a good way to practice floating and moving through the water without having to worry about holding your breath.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t worry if you have trouble keeping your entire body afloat. Your legs may angle slightly downward, which is fine.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Practice “bobbing” in the deep end. Go to deeper water and hold on to the side of the pool or a ladder. Submerge your whole body while you exhale, then come up to inhale. Do this several times, and try to exhale for longer than you inhale. This will help you get comfortable breathing when you can’t touch the bottom of the pool.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Mastering Basic Motions\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Mastering-Basic-Motions\">Mastering Basic Motions</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Practice treading water. Once you are in the pool, move your legs back and forth in a scissor motion, keeping them straight but not rigid. Then put both arms in the water and gently wave them back and forth horizontally, as if you are smoothing out the water beneath you.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Swim with your legs while holding onto a flotation device. Kicking properly is a very important part of swimming, and it can be easier to develop your technique when you don’t have to think about your arms at the same time. Get a kick board or pool noodle and use it to support your upper body in the water while you move yourself forward with your legs.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-11.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Practice the flutter kick by moving your legs as if you were walking. This is the most basic swimming kick, and you can do it by keeping your legs straight and moving them back and forth in the water. Practice this while holding a flotation device until you feel confident.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>While your legs should mostly be straight, it’s okay to let your knees bend by an inch or two as you move them through the water. Keeping them rigid may actually slow you down.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Do a breast stroke kick by pushing your legs out in circular motions. While holding on to a flotation device, practice moving through the water by bending your knees up towards your sides, then kicking them outwards and bringing them back together behind you. Your feet should flex outward as you kick, and your legs should stay under the water.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Work on your arm strokes. You can do this while standing in the water until you get comfortable, then combine it with kicking to move through the water. Move your arms forward in alternating circles with your hands slightly cupped. Try to “scoop” the water backwards as you move your arms.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep your arms as straight as possible, and extend them as far as possible when reaching forward.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Learning Swimming Techniques\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Learning-Swimming-Techniques\">Learning Swimming Techniques</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Do a backstroke to practice swimming with your face out of the water. Float on your back with your legs stretched out straight. Gently move your legs in a flutter kick and move your arms through the water in wide circles like windmills. Be careful not to splash too much with your legs, as this will slow you down and make you tired faster.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-13.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Typically, you should move backwards in the direction your head is pointing when doing the backstroke. Your arms should be moving backwards like you are pitching underhand.</li> \n    <li>When learning new swimming techniques such as a backstroke, consider working with a coach or instructor so that they can observe your form and help you improve.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Practice doing a side-stroke. Keeping your head above water, move sideways by reaching one arm forward and stretching the other out behind you, then bring both arms in towards your body. You can do a kind of sideways breaststroke kick by bending both knees, kicking one out in front of you and the other behind you, then bringing them back together.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Reach your arms out at the same time you kick your legs, then bring them all back in at the same time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Swim-the-Breaststroke\" title=\"Swim the Breaststroke\"> breaststroke</a> to practice exhaling underwater. For this stroke, both your arms and legs will be extending out and away from your body and then circling back in. Do a breaststroke kick while your arms move out straight in front of your chest, then sweep to the side as if you are parting the water in front of you.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-14.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You should exhale when your hands and knees are coming forward, and come up to inhale when you’re pushing back with your arms and legs.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Learn the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Swim-Freestyle\" title=\"Swim Freestyle\"> freestyle</a> once you’re comfortable holding your breath. This is similar to the backstroke, but you’ll be floating on your stomach. Do a flutter kick and move your arms forward through the water in a windmill motion. Exhale for 3 arm strokes, then turn your head to the side to inhale on the 4th stroke.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Learn to Swim As an Adult Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-15.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you are dedicated to becoming a strong swimmer, consider adding regular cardio workouts to your exercise routine. Building up your strength can be a big help in improving your form and overall abilities.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"5a615556b9168afeedaad3c638e6b1b3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn23@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-10-449_134d67add09eb455.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":49194,"destBytes":33074,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn23@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-10-449_134d67add09eb455.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn94@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-30-822_5dd8bb4103f99a6f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-3.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn62@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-29-613_22242791553fd769.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn53@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-31-366_2004cfc9528d6ead.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn65@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-31-820_4820f224a45fad47.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-28-948_1132c0f8a749605d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-11.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn57@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-32-199_0ae557f892977f08.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn73@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-418_421889c02d495b6d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn53@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-28-950_1cd724ab386195f8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn24@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-29-414_14d0d97a7b983b47.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-13.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn42@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-284_be8d886deb5f71ae.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn50@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-911_cf1b28e45eeb59e7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-14.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn61@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-31-813_a51c31158a6c8db3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-15.jpg/aid9610391-v4-728px-Learn-to-Swim-As-an-Adult-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn20@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-29-100_7ec78785494b1afa.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590203},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to French Knit","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If you'd love to learn how to knit but struggle with using the needles, start with a knitting dolly. To French knit, you simply wrap yarn around a hollow dolly that has pegs at the top. Work the yarn around the pegs to create a long knit cord that comes out of the bottom of the dolly. It's a great introduction to knitting that will give you the confidence to try larger projects. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Setting up the Knitting Dolly\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Setting-up-the-Knitting-Dolly\">Setting up the Knitting Dolly</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Gather your yarn and knitting dolly. Buy a knitting dolly that has 4 pegs at the top. You'll also need yarn that is thin enough to pass through the center of the knitting dolly. Place a darning needle, crochet hook, and scissors at your work space.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"French Knit Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid413292-v4-728px-French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a multicolored effect, choose variegated yarn where the color fades and changes in a single skein.</li> \n    <li>If you want to make your own dolly, stick 4 push pins around the edge of a spool of thread.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Slip-Knot\" title=\"Make a Slip Knot\">Tie a slip knot</a> at the end of the yarn. Hold the end of the yarn and twist it into a loop. Leave a 6 to 8 inch (15 to 20 cm) tail at the end of the yarn. While you hold the ends of the yarn, use the fingers on your other hand to pull the loop about 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide. Bring the yarn that's connected to the skein through the loop about halfway. You'll see a loose knot form.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You won't need to secure the slip knot onto 1 of the pegs, but the knot will make it easier to pull the yarn through the dolly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Thread the yarn through the center of the dolly. Lower the slip knot down through the center of the knitting dolly and snag the slip knot with the crochet hook. Use the hook to pull the yarn completely through the dolly, so about 4 inches (10 cm) of yarn comes out the bottom.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Hold the dolly with 1 hand and the working yarn with your other hand. If you're right-handed, hold the knitting dolly with your left hand. Take your right hand and hold the yarn that's coming out of the top of the dolly. The yarn will still be attached to the skein, so you may need to unroll the skein a little so you have some more yarn to work with.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you're left-handed, hold the dolly with your right hand and use the left hand to hold the working yarn.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wrap the yarn clockwise around each peg. Keep the tail yarn secure on the table or hold it in your left hand so the working yarn is taut. Take the working yarn at the top of the dolly and wrap it around 1 of the pegs clockwise. Pull the yarn over the the next peg that's counterclockwise. The yarn should pass through the center of the dolly. Continue to wrap each peg in a clockwise motion before moving to the next peg.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once you've wrapped each peg once, you're ready to begin French knitting.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Knitting the Cord\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Knitting-the-Cord\">Knitting the Cord</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wrap yarn around each peg again. Make a second loop of yarn around each peg by wrapping the yarn around each peg again. Remember to wrap the yarn around each peg in a clockwise motion before moving on to the next peg.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Lift each loop over each peg to make a row of stitches. Take a pick or darning needle and lift the bottom loop of a peg onto it. Lift the loop up and over the other loop on the peg so the stitch drops into the center of the dolly. Move counterclockwise along the dolly, making a stitch for each peg.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wrap another round of loops around the pegs. Take the working yarn and wrap it around each peg in a clockwise motion. Remember to work once around the dolly in counterclockwise direction. You should now have 2 loops on each peg.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Lift the loops to make another row of stitches. Use the pick or darning needle to lift the lower loop over the top loop. Drop the stitch through the center and work around the dolly counterclockwise. You'll start to see a stretchy, 4-sided knitted tube come out of the bottom of the dolly.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Continue to French knit until the cord is as long as you like. Keep making loops and stitching them through the center of the dolly. You may need to pull your stitches tight by tugging the yarn tail that comes out of the bottom. When you're ready to cast off, leave a single loop on each peg.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The cord will extend out of the bottom of the knitting dolly as it becomes longer.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Casting Off\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Casting-Off\">Casting Off</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Lift a single loop from 1 peg directly onto the next peg. To begin casting off, lift the single loop from a peg using the pick or darning needle. Lift it off the peg and drop it onto the next peg that's counterclockwise to it. This peg will now have 2 loops while the original peg won't have any.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You should now have 3 pegs with loops and 1 peg without loops.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make a stitch and transfer the remaining loop on the next peg. To cast off, use your pick or darning needle to lift the bottom stitch up and over the stitch on the peg. Drop it through the center, so only 1 loop remains on the peg. Lift the remaining loop up and onto the peg that's next to it counterclockwise.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You'll now have 2 pegs without stitches.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cast off to leave a single loop on the last peg. Tug on the bottom of the cord to tighten the remaining loop on the peg. Cut the yarn to leave a 5-inch (12.5 cm) tail and thread your darning needle on it.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Tie off the last loop and weave the tail through the center of the cord. Take the yarn on the darning needle and lift the remaining loop onto the needle. Pull the yarn tightly to knot the loop so you can lift it off the peg. Insert the darning through the hollow center of the cord and pull it back out about 2 inches (5 cm) from the bottom. Trim the yarn so it's flush with the cord.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/French-Knit#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Use your French knit cord. For quick jewelry, sew the ends of the cord together. Use the circle to make bracelets or necklaces that you can embellish with beads, sequins, or crystals. You can also sew the cord together to make swatches of fabric for doll's clothes or simple hats and scarves.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:French-Knit-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"French Knit Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/French-Knit-Step-15.jpg/aid413292-v4-728px-French-Knit-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Remember that you can sew together several French knit cords to make larger knit items such as blankets or sweaters.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Yarn</li> \n  <li>Knitting dolly or spool</li> \n  <li>Pick</li> \n  <li>Darning needle</li> \n  <li>Crochet hook</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=French-Knit&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap href=\"https://youtu.be/p-mH-3zB84k?t=220\">https://youtu.be/p-mH-3zB84k?t=220</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 07 Aug 2021 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid413292-v4-728px-French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"05702fd27b6cf792d5bae1e79d92e851","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn42@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-24-797_9463c78184dc32c8.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":63243,"destBytes":38596,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid413292-v4-728px-French-Knit-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn42@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-24-797_9463c78184dc32c8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/French-Knit-Step-15.jpg/aid413292-v4-728px-French-Knit-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn78@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-31-410_8f63b958da6dbb66.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590221},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Calibrate Binoculars","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Seeing detail from a far distance is almost impossible without a good set of binoculars. If you’re trying to birdwatch or see something from far away, you’ll need to make sure your binoculars are correctly calibrated to your eyes. To do this, you’ll need to properly set the distance between both eyepieces. Then, you’ll adjust the focusing rings, or diopters, to make the image sharp and clear. When done correctly, amazing details will be visible from a far distance. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Calibrate-Binoculars&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Calibrate-Binoculars&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Adjusting the Barrels and Eyepieces\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adjusting-the-Barrels-and-Eyepieces\">Adjusting the Barrels and Eyepieces</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Rotate the eyecup so it’s extended if you don’t wear eyeglasses. Turn the eyecups counterclockwise to raise them up from the body of the binoculars. If you wear eyeglasses, you can keep the eyecups retracted, or turn them clockwise to tighten them against the body of the binoculars.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Extending your eyecups will allow you to fit them around your eye, which will block out light you’d normally see in your peripheral vision.</li> \n    <li>Retracted eyecups will give you a wider field of view, so you may want to turn them clockwise if you're trying to see a wider image.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Attach the rubber cups to the eyepieces if you have them. Some binoculars come with a rubber cup that you can fit around the eyepiece. If yours came with one, use it for more comfortable viewing. Fit the slightly recessed end of the cups over both of the eyepieces so that they are snug and don’t slide off.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/03/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want to use the rubber cup but have glasses, roll the extended rubber back so that you can look through the binoculars with your glasses on.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Grip both barrels and bend the center of the binoculars to fit your eyes. The barrels are the 2 tube pieces connected to the lenses. Look through the binoculars and grip the barrels by the sides. Then, bend your binoculars up and down at the center so that both your eyes fit over the lenses. When you look through the eyepiece, you should see one circular image. If you see a double image, then you need to readjust the barrels.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The distance between everyone’s eyes differ, so you’ll need to adjust the barrels to fit your eyes so that the binoculars fit your face.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Calibrate-Binoculars&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Focusing the Binoculars\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Focusing-the-Binoculars\">Focusing the Binoculars</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Hold the binoculars up to your eyes and focus on an object. Select a stationary object in the distance to look at. If the image is blurry when viewing it through your binoculars, it means that you have to adjust the focus.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Even if the image is clear, you may want to calibrate your binoculars to achieve an even sharper image.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cover the right lens on the binoculars and focus with your left eye. Hold the palm of your hand over the right lens to cover it. If the image is blurry when you look with your left eye, it means that you need to adjust the focusing ring, in the center of your binoculars.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The focusing ring puts the object that you're looking at in focus while the diopter on the right eyepiece compensates for the differences between your left and right eye.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Adjust the focusing ring in the center of the binoculars. The focusing ring is the wheel in the center of your binoculars, in between both barrels. Rotate the ring left and right until the image becomes clear in your left eye.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>After you’re done focusing the left eyepiece, take your hand off the lens.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cover the left lens and focus with your right eye. Close your left eye and try to focus on the image with just your right eye. If the image isn't clear, it means you need need to adjust the diopter on the right eyepiece.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the vision in both of your eyes is the same, then you might not have to adjust the diopter on the right eyepiece.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Adjust the diopter on the right eyepiece. The diopter is the wheel on the eyepiece. This helps compensate for the differences in vision in your individual eyes. Rotate the diopter until you can see the object clearly with your right eye while the left lens is still covered.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Focusing on one eye at a time will make calibrating your binoculars easier.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look through the binoculars and note the diopter settings. Look through the binoculars with both eyes. The binoculars should feel comfortable and the object should be in focus. Most binoculars will come with markings on the diopter. Take note of where both diopters are so you know where to adjust them if they get changed or someone uses your binoculars.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Calibrate-Binoculars#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Calibrate Binoculars Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid138468-v4-728px-Calibrate-Binoculars-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once you get the correct calibration, you shouldn’t have to change it again.</li> \n    <li>If the image is still blurry, you may need to adjust the diopter in the center of the binoculars.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Calibrate-Binoculars&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap
