</ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 11 Aug 2021 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-1.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"6bb5447326427b1866459b65e6bc5bb0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn29@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-26-842_51ff8baa17cc8e1b.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":35399,"destBytes":18752,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-1.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn29@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-26-842_51ff8baa17cc8e1b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-2.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn13@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-30-845_13f41301c5b280eb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-3.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn97@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-32-484_0a12d5243f8e0875.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-4.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn84@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-29-366_376002ed72f8a63c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-5.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn65@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-31-476_bee2dcb2bcb13f05.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-6.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn10@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-31-642_e85277858291e5df.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-7.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn17@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-29-081_29ae22f45eb5860a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-8.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn46@2020_4/2021/08/15/03-53-29-723_04a77161224356fb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-9.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn25@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-975_b8f4808c3af922b5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-10.jpg/aid12661909-v4-728px-Express-Anger-in-a-Relationship-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn18@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-32-888_7f098bf22f9e5b22.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590203},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Be in a Relationship for the First Time","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Getting into a serious relationship is so exciting, but we know it can be a little nerve-wracking if you haven’t been in one before. When it’s your first time dating someone, it sometimes feels a bit tricky to know exactly what you should do or say. If you want to build a loving and lasting connection with your partner, we have you covered. Keep reading for some general advice to strengthen the bond with your partner and ways to keep your relationship the most fun and exciting! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Try new things together.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Try-new-things-together.\">Try new things together.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Make some exciting memories together so you keep growing together. You might get bored of doing the same thing every time you hang out with your partner, so find new opportunities to keep things interesting. Look for activities that neither of you has done before and give them a chance. Enjoy your time together as you learn and experience it for the first time. Some things you can do include:<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Visiting a museum</li> \n    <li>Cooking a new recipe</li> \n    <li>Taking an art class</li> \n    <li>Learning to dance</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Surprise them with a gift.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Surprise-them-with-a-gift.\">Surprise them with a gift.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>This lets your partner know that you were thinking about them. Whenever you stop at the store, pick up something that reminds you of your partner. You could buy their favorite candy, a magazine they always read, or even something they’ve said they wanted for a while. The next time you see them, give them the gift and let them know it was just because you were thinking of them.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t buy gifts only because you expect to get some in return.</li> \n    <li>Buy a few things during a single trip and keep them hidden away. The next time your partner has a bad day, you’ll have a gift ready for them so they can cheer up.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Give them compliments.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Give-them-compliments.\">Give them compliments.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Brighten their day by saying what you admire about them. Everyone loves to hear compliments, so get used to saying a few to your partner every day so they feel loved. Start with a phrase like “I love” or “I value” to show your appreciation. Say a specific quality about your partner that’s genuine and positive so they know how you feel about them.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you could say something like, “I love getting lost in your eyes.”</li> \n    <li>Compliments can be about characteristics as well. For example, you might say, “I appreciate how understanding you are.”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Plan some fun dates.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Plan-some-fun-dates.\">Plan some fun dates.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Keep your connection strong by going out and spending time with each other. Try to plan at least one date night a week so you can get out of the house and do something fun together, and take turns planning dates so you both have the opportunity to pick some fun activities. There are so many options you can do, but a few fun date ideas you can try include:<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-4.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Having a picnic at a park</li> \n    <li>Spending the day at the beach</li> \n    <li>Seeing a movie</li> \n    <li>Visiting a zoo</li> \n    <li>Going ice skating</li> \n    <li>Pretending you’re a tourist in your town and visiting all the small shops</li> \n    <li>Taking a walk in a scenic spot<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Going to a farmer's market<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Build up your physical intimacy.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Build-up-your-physical-intimacy.\">Build up your physical intimacy.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Showing your affection makes your bond so much stronger. As you get more comfortable with your partner, you’ll probably want to feel even closer to them. Take it slow at first and don’t feel pressured to go right into something like sex. When the time feels right, try holding their hand, snuggling up against them, giving them a big hug, or <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Kiss\" title=\"Kiss\">kissing</a> them to show just how much you care!<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-5.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Rushing into sex or things you’re not comfortable with could have a negative impact on your intimacy later on.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Always respect your partner’s boundaries. If there’s something they don’t like or don’t want to do, such as public displays of affection, listen to them and avoid doing it.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Communicate openly and honestly.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Communicate-openly-and-honestly.\">Communicate openly and honestly.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Having deep talks builds a stronger connection and prevents misunderstandings. You can’t grow closer to someone if you don’t let them get to know you more. Make some time every day to chat and catch up about your days. Let your partner know what’s going on in your life and listen to them without interrupting while they talk with you. Don’t be afraid to open up about your hobbies, childhood, or life since it shows your partner you’re comfortable around them.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It can be really hard to admit when you aren't happy something with something in the relationship, but talking about it is an important step to working through it as a couple.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Remember that your partner isn’t a mind reader. They won’t know what you’re thinking or feeling for sure until you say something.</li> \n    <li>If you do have to bring up a problem to your partner, try telling them what you think would fix it, as well. Then, you can listen to their ideas about how to work through it.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Treat them how you’d want to be treated.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Treat-them-how-you’d-want-to-be-treated.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Treat-them-how-you.E2.80.99d-want-to-be-treated.\">Treat them how you’d want to be treated.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Only doing what one person wants could lead to a controlling relationship. Show your partner respect and they’ll want to do the same for you. Invest your time equally between what you want to do and what your partner wants to do so it stays balanced. Even though you may not want to do everything that they want to, find a way to compromise so you both feel satisfied.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you might take turns picking what movies you watch so it doesn’t feel one-sided.</li> \n    <li>Look at things from your partner’s perspective so you can understand how they’re feeling better.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Celebrate their achievements.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Celebrate-their-achievements.\">Celebrate their achievements.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You and your partner feel happier when you get excited together. Whenever your partner succeeds, sincerely congratulate them and get pumped up with them. Do everything you can to keep the excitement alive and to make the rest of the day great, like going out to eat or watching their favorite movie.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-8.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if your partner did well on a test they were nervous about, you could say something like, “Honey that’s so awesome! You worked so hard and I’m so proud of you. Should we get some dinner to celebrate?”</li> \n    <li>Couples that celebrate together are less likely to fight and have more satisfying relationships.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Be supportive of your partner.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Be-supportive-of-your-partner.\">Be supportive of your partner.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Show that you care for them even when they’re struggling. Just like you should celebrate during happy moments, be present when your partner’s having a bad day. Offer to listen to them if they need to vent, talk through how to manage a situation, or just be a shoulder for them to cry on. You don’t need to solve the problems they’re having, but you should at least still be there for them.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-9.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Think about what you’d want from your partner if you were going through a tough situation so you can do the same.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Apologize when you’re wrong.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Apologize-when-you’re-wrong.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Apologize-when-you.E2.80.99re-wrong.\">Apologize when you’re wrong.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You’ll build more trust and respect when you recognize the issue. Everyone makes mistakes, but you still have to take responsibility for them. Whenever you realize you said something wrong or hurtful to your partner, apologize to them. Be genuine as you let your partner know that you did something wrong and ask for their forgiveness.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you got into a heated argument, you could say, “I realize I was acting defensive when you were trying to talk to me earlier, and I’m so sorry. I should have just listened without interrupting. Can you forgive me?”</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Work through any conflicts together.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Work-through-any-conflicts-together.\">Work through any conflicts together.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Communicate your issues so you can learn and move on from them. Disagreements are normal in a relationship, so don’t get worried if there are some harder conversations. Take a breather to collect thoughts before talking it out. Clearly explain how you’re feeling and what made you feel that way. Give your full attention to your partner as they explain their side of it as well. Discuss some possible solutions to the problem that you can both agree on so you know what to do moving forward.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use “I” statements when you’re talking through an issue so you don’t shift the blame. For example, say, “I feel lonely because I don’t have a lot of time to see you during the week,” instead of, “You always spend time with friends instead of me.”</li> \n    <li>Only focus on the current issue rather than talking about a lot of things at once.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Say “I love you” when you’re ready.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Say-“I-love-you”-when-you’re-ready.\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Say-.E2.80.9CI-love-you.E2.80.9D-when-you.E2.80.99re-ready.\">Say “I love you” when you’re ready.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Show that you’re caring and committed, but only when you’re sure of it. There’s never a “right” time to say those 3 words in a relationship, but ask yourself if it’s what you’re truly feeling. If you really do admire and love your partner, tell them face-to-face the first time so it’s the most meaningful. We know that it’s a little scary expressing your feelings, so it’s okay to wait until you think your partner will say it back, but you might just feel better letting it out.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-12.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t get discouraged if your partner doesn’t say it back immediately. They might just need a little more time to feel the same way.</li> \n    <li>Wait until you’re in the relationship for at least a few weeks before saying “I love you,” since saying it too early could sound clingy or creepy.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14\" title=\"Edit section: Keep being yourself.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Keep-being-yourself.\">Keep being yourself.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>You shouldn’t have to change who you are for the other person. You had your own life and goals before you started dating, so keep pursuing the things you wanted. Give yourself a few minutes every day to reflect on how you’re feeling and what you want to achieve. Take care of your needs completely, and don’t be afraid to talk about them with your partner so they can help out any way they can.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-13.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You only need to do things that you want to do, so don’t feel pressured into a decision by your partner if it’s something you don’t agree with.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15\" title=\"Edit section: Make time for friends and hobbies.\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Make-time-for-friends-and-hobbies.\">Make time for friends and hobbies.</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Split your time so you don’t feel burnt out on the relationship. Even though you may want to spend every minute with your partner, you still have to maintain your other friendships. Keep plans that you made with your friends and set aside some “me-time” so you can get some space to be alone too. Try to devote about 50% of your free time to see your partner, 30% to hang out with friends, and about 20% to be on your own.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Be in a Relationship for the First Time Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-14.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try to make friends with your partner's friends, too! When they're around, strike up conversations with them to find out what you have in common and just be generally friendly and open with them.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If your partner gets angry or jealous that you’re hanging out with other people, then it could be a warning sign of an unhealthy relationship.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>It’s completely normal to feel a little stressed or anxious when you’re in a new relationship. Take a step back and think about why you’re feeling that way so you can talk it through with your partner.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Watch out for signs of an unhealthy relationship, such as your partner trying to control you, blaming you for things, or bullying you.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 15 Aug 2021 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"4847859c5641255f7f6e3ecce8c02ae6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn40@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-28-574_4367bf98dfa27600.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":75348,"destBytes":51348,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn40@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-28-574_4367bf98dfa27600.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn69@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-31-491_48e90ad0886715df.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn89@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-31-118_07b789fa9917c9f5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-4.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn62@2020_6/2021/08/15/03-53-30-619_b94c035696116303.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-5.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn5@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-779_a3e6e710863103e7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn90@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-31-875_435a24db639c81ae.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn74@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-31-859_2408c2a8009042bd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-8.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn95@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-640_1b80d56aecefb5a1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-9.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn2@2020_1/2021/08/15/03-53-31-959_882915f04ac42ac9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn12@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-29-074_b8dc60b86b3a0c0e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn18@2020_2/2021/08/15/03-53-30-923_72f340a189d93e48.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-12.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn25@2020_3/2021/08/15/03-53-31-221_8c78eac4bdf69a7f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-13.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn74@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-29-087_efd01f61d3a2204b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-14.jpg/aid12649763-v4-728px-Be-in-a-Relationship-for-the-First-Time-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn6@2020_5/2021/08/15/03-53-31-861_5c402cb849146efe.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1628999590242},{"createdTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","updatedTime":"2021-08-15 11:53:10","title":"How to Extend Speaker Wires","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You've found the perfect spot for your speakers and stereo equipment, and now you're ready to hook it all up—but your speaker wire isn't long enough to connect it to the amp. For a quick fix, you can twist the wires together and tape them. This isn't a great long-term option though, because the wires can pull apart and short out your system.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> For a more permanent solution, use crimp connectors or solder the wires together. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cutting and Stripping\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cutting-and-Stripping\">Cutting and Stripping</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Double-check that your speaker is disconnected before you start. Unplug the power to the speaker and disconnect the speaker wire from your amp. If there's any power running to the speaker, you could be seriously hurt when you start working with the wires.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/88/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Match the size of your replacement and existing wire. For the best sound results, use stranded (not solid) speaker wire that's the same gauge (AWG) as your existing wire. Some wires will have the gauge printed down the side of the wire. If yours doesn't, place the wire in the holes of your wire cutter until you find the hole it fits in most closely. The number that's printed beside that hole is the wire gauge.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also cut a small piece of the wire and take it with you to a store that sells audio supplies so they can tell you.</li> \n    <li>Speaker wire ranges from 10AWG (which is very thick) to 20AWG (which is very thin). 18 gauge (AWG) is the most popular size, and it's usually used for distances of up to . 16 gauge is also common, especially for distances up to .<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You can splice 2 differently-sized wires together, as long as they're close in gauge (like 18AWG and 16AWG).</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Measure and cut your extra speaker wire. Use a tape measure to find how much extra length you need on your wire. However, add at least to that measurement. You'll need a little extra slack in the wire, since too much tension could damage the connection on your speakers or amp or cause the wire to pull free.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup> Then, use wire cutters to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-Speaker-Wire\" title=\"Cut Speaker Wire\">cut the extra speaker wire</a> to that length.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Many wire strippers also act as wire cutters, so you may not need two separate tools for this.</li> \n    <li>Consider off-setting the cuts on the negative and positive wire instead of cutting them straight across. For instance, you might make the positive end of the existing wire longer than the negative. Then, on the extension wire, you'd cut the positive side shorter than the negative. This off-set will make the finished wire less bulky, and there's no chance the positive and negatives will touch.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Strip-Wire\" title=\"Strip Wire\">Strip the ends</a> of both pieces of wire. Your speaker wire should look like 2 small tubes attached together. Carefully pull these apart, so the wire forms a Y shape.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> Then, clamp a wire stripper about from the end of the wire—squeeze just firmly enough to hold the wire in place, but not so tightly that you damage the wire beneath. Pull the wire firmly with your free hand. The insulation should slide off, exposing the bare wire without damaging it.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do this for both the positive and negative sides on the extension wire.</li> \n    <li>If the bare wires are already exposed on your existing speaker cord, you may not need to strip them again. If the wires look frayed, though, it's a good idea to cut them shorter and strip them so you have a fresh piece of wire to work with. Cut the wire as close to the frayed pieces as possible.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Twisting and Taping\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Twisting-and-Taping\">Twisting and Taping</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Twist the positive ends of the two wires together. Find the positive sides of your existing wire and the extension. Use your fingers to gently spread apart the strands that make up the wire to increase the contact between the two wires. Interlace the two bare pieces of wire through each other at the base so they make a V shape, then twist them together in a clockwise motion until they're connected tightly.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If there's any identifying feature on one side of the wire—like if one side is black and the other is colored, or if one side is striped, printed, stamped, or molded—that's the positive side. Also, if one side of the wire is silver and the other is gold, the gold side is positive.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Connect the negative ends of the wires. Take the two remaining pieces of bare wire on your extension. These will be the two negative sides. Twist these sides together just like you did for the positive ends—interlace the strands in a V shape, then spin the wires until they're wound together tightly.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Wrap each set of wires in electrical tape. Starting on the positive wires, wrap a piece of tape around the insulation on one side of the connection. Keep wrapping the tape over itself in a spiral until you've completely covered all of the bare wire.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> Then, repeat that on the negative side of the wires.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do not leave any bare wire showing at all. If the positive and negative sides of the wire touch, your speaker could short out and be permanently damaged. You'll also risk being shocked if you touch the bare wire while the speaker is on.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Give each set of wires a light tug to make sure they're secure after you tape them.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Go around the whole wire with more tape. Although all of the bare wire is now covered, you still have two separate pieces of wire that are split in the middle. This could potentially create a weak spot in the wire, so press the two sides together and wrap the whole thing in more electrical tape to create a secure single wire.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Although this will help stabilize the wire, the connection could still loosen over time, especially if you move the wire or put a lot of pressure on it. Eventually, that could cause a short that could damage your stereo equipment.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Crimp Connector\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Crimp-Connector\">Using a Crimp Connector</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Twist each bare end of wire tightly. Don't worry about connecting the wire yet. Just use your fingers to twist the positive and negative ends of both pieces of wire until you can't see any individual strands.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Identify the positive ends and negative sides of the wires. Look at your speaker wire and find the side that's red, gold, printed, or stamped. This is the positive side. Find the positive end of the extension wire, as well. Be sure to keep track of which side is which—if you attach a positive wire to a negative one, you could short out your speakers, permanently damaging them.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d6/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Push each set of wires into a crimp connector. Insert the positive end of your existing speaker wire into the first crimp connector as far as the bare wire will go. Then, insert the positive end of the extension wire into the other end of the connector. Put the negative ends of the wires into a second connector in the same way.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-11.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Double-check that there isn't any bare wire showing on either side. If there is, pull that end of the wire out of the connector and cut the bare wire a little shorter.</li> \n    <li>Make sure you choose the right crimp connector for your type of wire. They're usually color-coded—yellow for 10-12 AWG, blue for 14-16 AWG, and red for 18-22 AWG. You might see crimp connectors called butt connectors or butt splices—these terms all refer to the same thing!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clamp down on each connector with a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Crimp-a-Wire\" title=\"Crimp a Wire\">crimp tool</a>. A crimp tool looks similar to a wrench, but it has spaces in its jaws where you can place a wire. Place one end of the crimp connector into one of these channels, then press down hard on the tool to crimp the connector onto the wire. Do the same on the other side of the connector.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-12.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Crimping the connector will lock it onto the wire, creating a permanent splice.</li> \n    <li>Don't use pliers or any other tool to crimp the wire—it won't hold the connector securely in place.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Double-check your connection by pulling on the wire. With the wire still held in the crimping tool, gently pull on the wire. If it comes loose, it wasn't secured and you'll need to start over with a new connector.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-13.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>After you check that the wires are secure, you can wrap the connectors in electrical tape for extra stability. Don't use the tape to stabilize poorly-secured connectors, though.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try a wire nut as a quick alternative to a crimp connector. Wire nuts work similarly to crimp connectors, but they aren't quite as secure. Just push the positive ends of the wires side-by-side into a wire nut, then turn the nut clockwise to intertwine the wires. Do the same for the negative sides.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-14.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Soldering the Wire\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soldering-the-Wire\">Soldering the Wire</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Twist the positive ends of each wire together. The positive side of the wire will be printed or stamped, or it may be red (the negative side will be black) or gold (the negative side will be silver). Lay the bare ends of each positive wire over each other to form an X. Then, rotate one side of the wire toward you and the other side away from you to twist the two wires together.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-15.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep twisting until the wires are connected firmly together.</li> \n    <li>Tuck the ends of the wire in neatly—if they're sticking up, they could pierce through the electrical tape you use at the end.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use clamps to hold your wire off of your work surface. Solder uses high heat, so it's important not to place the wires directly on a surface that could be damaged, like a wooden table. Try using a helping hands device to lift the wires—it's a small device with two metal clips that will hold the wire in place.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-16.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't have a helping hands device, you can improvise by clamping the wire between two alligator clips, then standing the clips on end. This won't be super-secure, though, so try not to bump the clips or the wire while you're working.</li> \n    <li>You could also work on a heat-safe surface, like a metal or concrete workbench.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Melt solder onto the bare wires. Place the tip of a hot soldering iron to the bare, twisted wire. At the same time, place a stick of solder against the wire. Once the iron heats the solder enough, the solder will melt, flowing over and into the speaker wire. Coat the wire completely in the solder from one end to the other.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-17.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Flip the wire over and repeat this on the bottom. Unclamp your wire and turn it over so the bottom is exposed. Then, melt solder over this side as well, until the bare speaker wire is completely covered.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-18.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have enough room to maneuver beneath the wire, you could just hold the soldering iron and solder under the wire and melt it that way, rather than flipping the wire over.</li> \n    <li>Once you've soldered the wire, let it cool for 5-10 minutes before you handle it.</li> \n    <li>Repeat the whole process to connect the negative sides of the speaker wire.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wrap the wire in electrical tape. Even though there's solder coating the wire, it still needs to be insulated—the solder is conductive, so if the positive and negative sides touch, the wire will short out. Wrap the whole splice in electrical tape, going from one end of the insulation to the other. Do this for both the positive and negative sides of the wire. To create a cleaner look, you can then pinch the positive and negative sides together, then wrap the whole thing in electrical tape as well.<sup id=\"_ref-26\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 26\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-26\">[26]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Extend Speaker Wires Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-19.jpg/aid11960-v4-728px-Extend-Speaker-Wires-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also use <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Heat-Shrink-Tubing\" title=\"Use Heat Shrink Tubing\">heat shrink tubing</a> to insulate the wires. Put the tubing on the wire before you splice the ends together, but keep it away from the heat of the soldering iron. Once the solder is cool, slide the tubing over the splice and use a heat gun or hair dryer to shrink it around the bare wire.<sup id=\"_ref-27\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 27\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Extend-Speaker-Wires#_note-27\">[27]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>When you're extending speaker wire, it's usually most convenient to do so permanently. If you think you might just need a temporary connection, though, you might want to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Banana-Plugs\" title=\"Use Banana Plugs\">use banana plugs</a> so you can easily disconnect and reconnect the wire.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Cut and Strip\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cut-and-Strip\">Cut and Strip</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Extra speaker wire</li> \n  <li>Measuring tape</li> \n  <li>Wire cutters/strippers</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Twist and Tape\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Twist-and-Tape\">Twist and Tape</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Electrical tape</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Crimp Connector\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Crimp-Connector\">Crimp Connector</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Crimp connector</li> \n  <li>Crimping tool</li> \n  <li>Electrical tape (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Solder\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Solder\">Solder</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Metal clamps or helping hands</li> \n  <li>Soldering iron</li> \n  <li>Solder</li> \n  <li>Electrical tape or heat-shrink tube</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hide-Speaker-Wires\" title=\"Hide Speaker Wires\">Hide Speaker Wires</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Wire-Speakers\" title=\"Wire Speakers\">Wire Speakers</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Install-Speakers\" title=\"Install Speakers\">Install Speakers</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Extend-Speaker-Wires&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span
